STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ROBERT GORDON
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
July 30, 2020
Kathleen Schultz
Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
1715 Sutherland Dr. SE
Kentwood, MI 49508-5072
RE: License #: CB410201260
Investigation #: 2020C0103030
Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
Dear Ms. Schultz:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For any repeat violations, include an assessment of why the previous
corrective action plan was ineffective.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and
your contract.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (517) 284-9740.
Sincerely,
Rorie Dodge-Garnaat, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
235 Grand, Ste 1305
P.O. Box 30650
Lansing, MI 48909
(517) 899-6024
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB410201260
Investigation #: 2020C0103030
Complaint Receipt Date: 05/21/2020
Investigation Initiation Date: 05/21/2020
Report Due Date: 07/20/2020
Licensee Name: Wellspring Lutheran Services
Licensee Address: 4100 Pier N. Blvd Ste. A
Flint, MI 48504-1487
Licensee Telephone #: (989) 262-7386
Administrator: Sean De Four, Designee
Licensee Designee: Sean De Four, Designee
Name of Facility: Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
Facility Address: 1715 Sutherland Dr. SE
Kentwood, MI 49508-5072
Facility Telephone #: (616) 281-4601
Original Issuance Date: 12/01/1991
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 06/29/2020
Expiration Date: 06/28/2022
Capacity: Unknown
Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
There are concerns the case worker is not following through with No
Family Team Meeting (FTM) agreements and not being truthful in
reporting.
The caseworker is failing to maintain appropriate boundaries. Yes
Additional Findings No
III. METHODOLOGY
05/21/2020 Special Investigation Intake
2020C0103030
05/21/2020 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
Administrator
05/21/2020 Contact - Document Sent
E-mail to Administrator and Director
05/21/2020 Contact - Document Sent
E-mail to Supervisor and worker
05/22/2020 Contact - Document Sent
Teams interviews set up with Worker and Supervisor
05/26/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Video Conference interview with the supervisor
05/26/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Video conference interview with the worker
05/26/2020 Contact - Document Received
E-mail from the supervisor
05/26/2020 Contact - Document Sent
E-mail to/from Worker 2
06/04/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Phone interview with Therapist
06/04/2020 Contact - Telephone call made
Message left for Youth A's mother.
2

06/29/2020 Contact - Document Received
Code of Conduct
06/29/2020 Exit Conference
07/28/2020 Inspection Completed-BCAL Sub. Compliance
ALLEGATION:
There are concerns the case worker is not following through with FTM agreements,
not being truthful in reporting, and failing to maintain appropriate professional
boundaries.
INVESTIGATION:
A complaint was received on 5/21/20 which stated the following:
In regards to Youth A’s case the case progress has been a concern since
October 2019, when mom was evicted from her residence while Youth A was in
her 10th month of treatment at her residential facility. Mom has struggled to find
housing in Grand Rapids and has been living with her adult daughter since then.
As of this summary, mom has secured housing, full time employment and has
achieved nearly 18 months of sobriety. She has met the expectations for a
parent involved in their child’s treatment at the residential facility, and she has
maintained excellent rapport with Youth A’s family therapist throughout the
therapists involvement in the case. The therapist began requesting monthly
family team meetings in November 2019, and the case has not moved forward
to reunification. The following is a summary of concerns that have come up in
this case since January 2020.
 Worker 1 did not accurately indicate what services mom and Youth A are
receiving during a 1/7/20 court hearing
 Worker 1 struggled to answer basic questions about the case during the
1/7/20 court hearing
 The residential therapist over heard Worker 1 tell a co-worker, “I’m freaking
out because I don’t know the answers to the questions they’re asking me
because I don’t know anything that’s going on in this case.”
 On 1/9/20 the residential therapist tried to contact Worker 1 and her
supervisor because Youth A was concerned her mother was incarcerated
however Wellspring did not answer or reply.
 Worker 1 has stated in FTM’s that lack of progress on the case has been
due to Youth A’s mothers lack of housing and mental health services yet
Youth A’s mother has restated repeatedly that she is receiving mental
health care and that she sees her final barrier to be housing. In the most
recent meeting in February 2020, Worker 1 reported there was a possibility
Youth A would not be allowed to return to her mother’s care due to the
language contained in the original court order. Youth A’s mother continues
3

to report that she feels she is not receiving the support she needs from
Wellspring.
Employee File Review: A memo from Worker 1’s employee file was provided on
5/22/20. The memo dated 2/5/20 stated that in November of 2019 Worker 1 met with
her supervisor to discuss getting behind on her cases. Worker 1 and her supervisor
discussed solutions for this. One of those solutions was to have weekly check-in’s
with her supervisor.
The memo also stated in January of 2020 Worker 1 got a co-worker to cover a visit
for her because she had to move a youth to residential. She ended up not moving
but Worker 1 still did not do the visit. It was also reported that Worker 1 did not
follow-up on case items and when it was brought up to Worker 1 by service
providers she was defensive and had an excuse as to why she had not done it.
It was further discussed that Worker 1 used profane language and connotation when
talking about a client while in the halls between the cubicles at the office. It was
reported that Worker 1 wished ill-will on one of her clients.
The memo indicated an improvement plan would be worked on between Worker 1
and her supervisor.
Foster Care Supervisor Interview: A video call took place with Worker 1's
Supervisor on 5/26/20. She stated that Worker 1 is very coachable. She has come a
long way since January's court hearing for Youth A. The supervisor said she has had
conversations with Worker 1 about her anxiety, as Worker 1 gets worked up easily.
Though she is doing better Worker 1 still has work to do. Worker 1 means well but
her delivery needs work. Worker 1 was written up on 2/5/20. She said she goes over
Worker 1's goals every time they meet. She stated Worker 1 is honest. Youth A's
mom and residential facility are not getting along with Worker 1. The residential talks
bad about Worker 1 to mom. The supervisor talked to the residential about this and
asked them to address concerns directly with her and Worker 1.
The supervisor stated she was not at the court hearing on 1/7/20 but she sent a
team lead to go with Worker 1. Worker 1 had the flu and did not feel well. During
court Worker 1 did say Youth A was in TFCBT but later corrected herself. Worker 1
was really flustered and thought she was going to throw up. She did indicate to the
team lead that she felt like she did not know the case. The residential therapist
overheard Worker 1 say this. The therapist said something to Worker 1 about it,
which made Worker 1 even more flustered. The Worker indicated something
incorrect about mom's therapy, but she said it because she was flustered not
because she did not know. The court clerk informed the supervisor that Worker 1
was flustered but that she did fine.
4

The supervisor stated that Worker 1 was on vacation when mom went to jail. No one
from the residential facility called the supervisor as instructed on Worker 1's out of
office message.
Regarding the case, the supervisor stated that Youth A made more progress than
mom. Mom does not like Worker 1, so Mom does not communicate well with Worker
1. Mom missed several drug screens and was not in counseling for a time. Mom is
currently in counseling and has been working with the residential facility on
parenting. Mom is homeless and lives with her adult daughter. They did get a dual
order so Youth A can return to mom if mom lives with her adult daughter and has
Family Reunification Program (FRP) in the home for 30 days but before FRP can be
put in place mom needs to move in with daughter. Youth A's lawyer and the judge
said no to an order allowing Youth A to go live with just mom. Mom said she wanted
to do it at her own home.
Worker 1 Interview: Worker 1 is the Foster Care Worker for Youth A. She was
interviewed on 5/26/20 via video call due to COVID-19. She stated that at the court
hearing in January she was not feeling well as she had the flu. She was flustered
and she did end up messing up by saying Youth A was in TFCBT but she corrected
herself. She also said Youth A's mother was not going to therapy when in fact the
mom was between therapists at that time. Worker 1 said she knew she was going to
throw-up so she went to the bathroom. Her co-worker came into the bathroom with
her. Worker 1 said she did not know the therapist was in the room until she asked if
Worker 1 was ok. Worker 1 said if she did say she did not know the case she may
have said it out of being sick and flustered as she does know the case.
Worker 1 said she was on vacation from 1/8/20 -1/15/20 and she turned her phone
off. She did have an out of office message to contact her supervisor. Worker 1 also
informed Youth A's residential placement and the therapist in person that she would
be on vacation. She said she notified all providers she would be out of town.
Regarding the case, Worker 1 said that Youth A's mother was not making progress
as of January. There was a period of time when she was not in therapy, she did not
have housing, and was not communicating with the worker. Now mom is doing
great. She is in therapy, has a full-time job, is living with her adult daughter and has
an apartment lined up. Mom has missed a few meetings with FRP but she is working
on re-scheduling those. Worker 1 said recently there has not been much
communication with mom. Worker 1 has told mom that she needs to be living with
her adult daughter and have FRP in place for 30 days in order for Youth A to be
returned to her.
Worker 1 said she meets weekly with her supervisor. Her supervisor helps her make
priority lists. She said the agency is supportive of her and she can go to her
supervisor, other supervisors, or her co-workers for help.
A message was left for Youth A’s mother, but a return call was never received.
5

Worker 2: An e-mail was sent to Worker 2 asking her about the court hearing in
January. She responded by writing: “During the court hearing on 1/07/2020, it was
pretty noticeable when Worker 1 was testifying that she did not feel well and was
going to vomit. When she was testifying, she tried to answer the questions but
struggled because she was trying to not get sick. She than looked at the judge and
asked to be excused because she was going to get sick. She then ran off the stand
and I followed her. In the bathroom, she was vomiting and became emotional and
stated she did not feel like she knew the case and was upset because she didn’t
know the answers to the questions. She than walked back into the court room and
apologized and said she didn’t feel well. Before she left the stand, the staff member
from the residential facility asked me if she was okay and if she needed help. I asked
if she meant with clarifying the information or because she was sick and she said
“Well both, she does not look good”. She than suggested I let the Guadian Ad Litem
(GAL) know she was sick, but Worker 1 than said something. When I was there, the
residential staff did not tell Worker 1 anything about not knowing the case.
Therapist Interview: Youth A's therapist from her residential facility was interviewed
via telephone on 6/4/20. She stated she has been working with Youth A since
August of 2019 and she thought Worker 1 started on Youth A's case in September.
The therapist said she does not feel she can trust what Worker 1 says. Youth A's
mom told her that Worker 1 talks to her about other clients. Mom also told the
therapist that she calls Worker 1 and Worker 1 does not call her back. Mom was
trying to find housing but Worker 1 was not able to find any resources for her. The
therapist stated that there was no movement in the case. Mom was enrolled in
mental health services the entire time. The therapist said she gets two sides of the
story and mom says Worker 1 is not honest. There is a difference between what
mom says and what Wellspring says. The therapist said mom is participating in
services with the residential facility and that mom is open and honest with them.
Worker 1 told her supervisor that mom and the therapist were talking about her, but
they were not.
Regarding the case, the therapist said that Youth A is nine to ten months past when
she should have left the facility. The therapist said that she took her concerns about
the case to a team meeting. She said she did not bring up concerns about Worker 1
herself. The therapist said that FRP is closing because mom is not meeting with
them.
A review of Youth A’s case file in MiSACWIS was completed. In the August 2019
Updated Service Plan (USP) Youth A was not ready to return home and mom was
having supervised visits. Mom was starting to participate in the Parent Agency
Treatment Plan (PATP). She was engaged in therapy but did not have employment
or housing. The November USP indicates Youth A was having weekend visits at the
facility with mom. Mom was staying sober and participating in therapy. Multiple
contacts indicate mom and worker called on housing resources, but mom was not
having any luck gaining housing. A contact in the file indicates the court was
6

contacted on 2/5/20 and reported to the supervisor that Youth A could not return to
mom under the current court order. Then on 3/25/20 the court order states "progress
was not made", continue placement but can be placed with mom in sisters home
with FRP in place 30 days before return home. Contacts indicated FRP had started
and the next court hearing was scheduled for June.
FTM’s were also reviewed. During the FTM from 12/19/19 the team discussed Youth
A returning home, but Youth A was acting out because she was not seeing a reward
for doing good (going home). The 1/28/20 FTM stated mom is working on getting
housing. Mom is compliant with other services. They discussed a possible discharge
for March. The 4/28/20 FTM stated the team was prepping Youth A to go home as
mom has housing. Discharge was discussed for May.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-06 Case Planning
Supervising Agency Requirements
Reasonable efforts must be made by the supervising agency.
The services offered and/or provided are considered reasonable
efforts and must be recorded in the case service plan and the
parent-agency treatment plan and service agreement; see FOM
722-08C, Parent-Agency Treatment Plan and Service
Agreement.
ANALYSIS: In reviewing the case file and talking to Worker 1 there is no
indication that worker 1 has not been following-up with providing
services to mom. Contacts indicate the worker has been in
contact with housing service providers and with mom to provide
her with resources. Mom could not be reached to dispute this.
Further there is no indication that Worker 1’s conduct at the
court hearing on 1/7/20 caused reasonable efforts not to be
made in this case. All case documents indicate it was mom’s
lack of housing that was keeping Youth A in residential.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
The caseworker is failing to maintain appropriate boundaries.
INVESTIGATION:
During the above complaint the following was alleged:
7

 The therapist stated that on 5/19/20 Worker 1 was scheduled for a video visit
with Youth A. Prior to Youth A getting on the call Worker 1 was applying
essential oils and disclosed that she was recently diagnoses with anxiety and
depression. Worker 1 stated she was afraid to take medication and that is
why she was applying the oils. She then started talking about having a panic
attack the last time she visited with Youth A in person on 3/19/20.
 Other concerns throughout the case include mom’s repeated statements that
she is not getting the support she needs from Wellspring and that Worker 1
had demonstrated poor professional boundaries with her. Mom reported that
Worker 1 openly complained about other clients in front of her and had
demonstrably declined their calls while transporting mom to appointments.
Mom also stated that Worker 1 talks to her about her (Worker 1’s) romantic
and family problems, needing to take mental health days, and complaining
about her heavy caseload.
As indicated above Worker 1 had previously been written up for stating that she
wished ill will on one of her clients, specifically that they would be harmed.
Foster Care Supervisor Interview: During her interview the supervisor stated she
had a conversation with Worker 1 about self-disclosure. Worker 1 admitted she did
say the things the therapist reported. The supervisor said Worker 1 needs additional
training on boundaries and self-disclosure. Worker 1 was written up on 2/5/20 for
talking poorly about clients.
Worker 1 Interview: During her interview, Worker 1 was asked about her video visit
with Youth A on 5/19/20. She stated she talked to the therapist first. The therapist
asked if Worker 1 was ok and Worker 1 told her she was dealing with anxiety and
she was worried about taking medication for it. Worker 1 said her supervisor
addressed this issue with her. Worker 1 said she had a panic attack after seeing
Youth A, not during the visit. Worker 1 said she went to the doctor and they said it
was a panic attack.
Worker 1 stated she has never complained about her clients in front of Youth A's
mom. All she has said is that there are other clients who go through the same
difficulties as her (mom). Worker 1 said she has talked about her personal life with
Youth A's mom and she would try to relate to her clients by saying she has been
through some of the things they have been through. She recognizes now she
crossed a boundary. She said she has told mom that she may not get back to her in
time because she is helping other families.
Therapist Interview: During her interview the therapist said Worker 1 was detailing
her mental health in a conversation with her. She said Youth A was not present for
the conversation. She said she was in the office and Worker 1 was at home. They
started the call by the two of them talking. Worker 1 talked about her having a panic
attack the last time Worker 1 met with Youth A. In January they had a review hearing
and Worker 1 was struggling. She messed up on Youth A's age and grade. The
8

Therapist looked at mom who was shaking her head about what Worker 1 was
saying. Worker 1 also did not give the correct information about Youth A's treatment.
Worker 1 was just trying to get through the hearing. Worker 1 left to go to the
bathroom. The therapist went to check on Worker 1 and Worker 1 was upset and
yelling that she did not know the case.
The Code of Conduct Policy for the agency was reviewed. The policy states that
“Employees and agents are expected to conform to the standards of their respective
professionals and exercise sound judgement in the performance of their duties…”
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all of the following:
(d) Staff qualifications.
ANALYSIS: The agency’s Code of Conduct Policy states employees are to
exercise sound judgement. Worker 1 did not do that when, as
reported by the therapist and Worker 1, she disclosed personal
information about herself to service providers and clients.
Additionally she was written up for wishing ill will on one of her
clients.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon acceptance of a corrective action plan it is recommended that this
investigation be closed with no further licensing action.
7/28/20
________________________________________
Rorie Dodge-Garnaat Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 30, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
9
